Background of the project

Cardiovascular risk will differ in an individual with age and health status. This could lead to different recommendations for the population; but also it could cause differences in the assessment of risk factors in individuals with more severe CVD risk. In the present case study it is suggested that the age of individuals diagnosed with ASCVD but not in the population at large is 60. The following considerations highlight the appropriateness of age-derived CVD guidelines for the specific population involved:
1) When assessing risk, a patient's baseline age, sex, and health status are not necessarily the same as the community average. Age is a key determinant of risk for these patients - as young adults have a higher chance of developing severe disease but are less likely to develop cardiovascular disease.
2) While age is the most important determinant of risk and will therefore be used most often, it is also important to remember that age can also influence health status, health behaviours, and health outcomes. A patient with advanced (advanced) cardiovascular disease will have different circumstances than a patient with a non-vivo disorder.
Some of the recommendations in the present case study for the guideline use should be based on age-specific recommendations, as this is a very individualised and complex issue. Age-derived risk and guidelines should be adapted to local circumstances but as a general guideline an age-derived and age-specific CVD risk calculator would be of considerable utility. This tool would then be readily accessible from the public health services.
The importance of age-derived risk is evident in this case study: it will give a better picture of the individual’s baseline risk of dying, disease stage, and progression to mortality. It will improve the risk-benefit analysis in risk stratification and planning, and therefore aid in the treatment and prevention of CVD. Older people may also benefit in certain areas of life such as health behaviour change and prevention efforts - for example, smoking cessation.
In summary, age-derived CVD risk calculators can be of considerable benefit for individualising care and decision making for individuals who are young and in better physical shapes. No, it wouldn't. There are many factors to consider. For some people, particularly older people, cholesterol levels will not go up and may even go down, because of a normal loss of fat during ageing. Most of the fat in our body is the same as the fat that makes up our joints, which is called free fatty acids. The amount of cholesterol is not the only factor affecting cholesterol levels. The amount of cholesterol which sticks to the walls of the blood vessels is called 'bad cholesterol'. This is a different type of cholesterol to 'good' cholesterol, and it can be difficult to prevent this form of cholesterol getting deposited in the walls of blood vessels.
People with diabetes are more likely to have high cholesterol levels because diabetes causes too much insulin to be used by the body. The pancreas produces too much insulin, which gets into the wall of the blood vessel, where it can stick to the cholesterol from the fat in the arteries. High numbers of cholesterol sticking to the walls of blood vessels also increases the risk of other types of blood vessel clogging - for instance it increases the risk of heart disease. This is why having the right level of cholesterol is such an important prevention for people with diabetes.

How does naltrexone relate to the NHS?
Naltrexone is used for the treatment of alcohol dependence and its co-use as part of a dual diagnosis treatment. Alcohol use disorder can affect several areas of a person's life. Naltrexone is a medication typically used to treat alcohol dependence. It is a synthetic compound that blocks the brain's receptors that facilitate the brain's response to alcohol. Naltrexone targets the brain's receptors, blocking the effects and withdrawal of alcohol. Naltrexone works by binding to the opiate receptors in the brain and stopping the effects of alcohol and its related drugs. As a result, the drug is sometimes known as Tranquilizing Drug.
In 2011, NICE published its opinion that naltrexone had not shown to be'substantially effective in reducing the impact of long-term substance use without diminishing treatment effectiveness.' NICE recommends that naltrexone should not be used for the treatment of alcohol dependence unless the individual's condition is stable. The UK Government has committed 20% of its 70-year-old population to treatment and naltrexone is therefore not recommended for the treatment of alcohol dependence. naltrexone is currently only recommended in certain contexts for the treatment of alcoholism and other alcohol dependence conditions. But what about those who are not in a position to make appropriate lifestyle changes to change or maintain their heart health and still have CVD? Is there a guideline for what lifestyle changes would be appropriate for a patient with CVD? According to NICE guidelines, lifestyle changes for any of the above CVD risk factors must be assessed in conjunction with other factors for cardiovascular risk. A patient at risk of CVD would make lifestyle changes to reduce cardiovascular risk, at the same time they would reduce their level of CVD risk. The difference between these two are the extent of lifestyle changes, and the proportion of lifestyle changes would be sufficient to reduce CVD risk.
So, for instance, one might have an atherosclerotic heart disease, high blood pressure, smoking, diabetes and so on, but some lifestyle behaviors such as maintaining a healthy body mass index, exercise, not drinking alcohol, have been proven to be associated with a lower risk of CVD. If you have an HbA1C less than 5.3%, you can still improve your CVD risk, but if you have diabetes, smoking, hyperlipidaemia or hypertension, you should make all steps in the lifestyle to be taken under these circumstances, so they can be considered part of the current NHS recommendations.
So, it seems sensible that a patient at risk of CVD may be in need of lifestyle changes, but it doesn't have to follow these guidelines. In fact, they may not even be in the position required to implement these changes, so we might need to use more discretion in terms of what type of changes are appropriate in the patient's particular situation.
The above guidance for lifestyle modification in the UK is provided by the UK's National Health Service (NHS). It does not have an SNH guideline, but it has some guidance for healthcare professionals.
If you have hypertension or hypercholesterolemia please make those lifestyle changes, if you have diabetes you want them to be in the same category. Lifestyle is only one part of CVD prevention and it's important to be able to identify at what point they started to do the above lifestyle changes.

Are there any questions regarding what risk factor for CVD may influence lifestyle adjustments that would limit the risk of CVD? The answer to these questions will directly impact the development of an effective CVD intervention.
This topic has important implications for patient safety, health literacy and the public health infrastructure in our country. Patients with CVD often have other health issues that are not adequately addressed through healthy lifestyle modifications, such as excessive alcohol consumption, diabetes, obesity, smoking, and poor nutrition. In this way, patients are at a higher risk for adverse outcomes. If patients have CVD, this is a time-consuming and costly intervention, whereas if they do not have CVD, this is not that time consuming and a great risk reduction benefit.
Awareness, understanding the influence of lifestyle modification on the risk of CVD among the general public, may have a large public health impact. For example, if all Chinese citizens had a balanced diet of fruits, vegetables, whole grain cereals, lean protein, and dairy products, CVD risk would be reduced by 1.69 (P=0.001),1 that is equivalent to lowering CVD risk to the 65% threshold. Given that only 2.8% of Chinese citizens will be considered at risk based on BMI, the overall proportion of Chinese citizens with CVD is only 0.7%. However, it would be prudent for the public to have greater access to public health resources like schools and clinics, which may increase the proportion of those with moderate CVD or CVD+1.1
We have reviewed data on the relationship between lifestyle modification and CVD risk from the literature. A greater proportion of the population should have a balanced diet, particularly fruits, vegetables, nuts, whole grains, dairy products, legumes, tofu, soybeans, and fish products to improve their risk of CVD, especially in China and Southeast Asia.4 The overall proportion of Chinese citizens with CVD is 0.7%.1 But, not enough will ever be achieved to improve CVD morbidity and mortality in China.3,4 A national government may need to increase resources and invest the necessary funds in public health infrastructure such as hospitals, clinics, and wellness centers. Public awareness campaigns and education on healthy lifestyle choices will play a significant role in decreasing CVD-related deaths, particularly in China.4
We also have reviewed data on the relationship between lifestyle modification and physical activity from the literature. A greater proportion of people with CVD will be active, particularly in Asian countries.5 Even more importantly, the overall proportion of Chinese citizens with CVD is 0.6%15 which means 65% of China's rural population will be active.6 The benefits of exercise and weight loss in reducing CVD will be great in China.6 However, the results for China are not always the same. For example, in the United States, only a minority of Asian adults and younger adults are overweight or obese, which is likely to lead to more sedentary lifestyles for the population.6 Other regions of the United States are more likely to adopt the Healthy Active Living (HA) guidelines. For instance in Connecticut only about 10% of the population is obese.
One possible limitation of the above review is the small sample sizes. The general public may benefit from the increased intake of fruit, vegetables, and low-salt and low-fat dairy products due to greater sodium intake from sodium additives, which makes it difficult to ascertain their effect on CVD.3,4
As this review highlights, the relationship between lifestyle modification and CVD has long been established, but more research is needed to better integrate this knowledge into public health policies and programs. These findings also point to an urgent need for more health education on nutrition and exercise among the public.

- Physical activity - is part of a broader physical activity risk assessment. It is not recommended for anybody with an inherited condition, such as diabetes or high cholesterol. It is not recommended for anyone with other risk factors that don't lead to physical inactivity such as being overweight and poor diet; for example, it is not recommended if a person has only recently started a vigorous training programme.
- Personal history of CVDs or other risk factors (eg smoking, family history of CAD or other risk factors for diabetes, heart failure, or any other condition that increases CVD risk) - is used to identify the individual's highest risk for developing CVD. It is not recommended for anyone with a history of hypertension, diabetes, or any other condition that increases CVD risk.

What are the main factors which affect the development of heart disease?
First, you have risk factors for heart disease.
Second, you can become a "bad," "not a good," "cardiac," "cardiovascular," or "cardiographic," person. In a good person, cholesterol, blood sugar, and body weight are controlled through diet and exercise and by your overall lifestyle. But these factors cannot compensate for risk factors for heart disease. When risk factors don't compensate for the factors associated with heart disease, they cause a decrease in heart health.
These three factors interact with each other to determine the overall extent of health at every age. In addition, each time the factors interact, we can go from "bad" to "good" in terms of risk factors. So it is that the heart disease or vascular risk factors - the factors which either increase the risk or mitigate the effects of these cardiovascular risk factors in a healthy person - can be manipulated to increase the chance of developing heart disease or to decrease or maintain the risk of developing heart disease.
Another important factor, and one which may be more important than risk factors, is the "family history." A family history of stroke, for instance, might contribute an individual's risk of developing heart disease. The more an individual has smoked before they were diagnosed with the heart disease, the more likely they are to become a good patient to be treated for heart disease.

The NICE guideline on preventing cardiovascular disease (from a review of scientific evidence), may give the following advice (and not a full set of evidence-based recommendations, in fact)!
- Screening is required annually in all people with risk factors for CVD (diabetes, hypertension, smoking, hypercholesterolaemia and obesity).
- There is a lack of evidence to recommend a minimum interval between yearly screening, although there is evidence to recommend screening between an average life-time risk assessment.
- Screening should include blood pressure measurement, lipid profile and cholesterol calculations.
- Blood pressure should be measured in patients with high or abnormal LDL cholesterol, for whom screening has not been recommended. If screening has not been recommended, one should consider that an individual with an abnormal blood cholesterol profile in relation to other individuals with a similar profile will benefit from intervention.
- This initial screening should be based on current lifestyle behaviours, ideally on a patient's own advice.
- This initial screening should be conducted at least at least annually
- If a person is already diagnosed with CVD, a regular follow-up is recommended - for example, to see if these lifestyle changes are being maintained, and if required other tests should be done, such as chest CT scan.

Dr Manjul Thiek, Consultant Cardiologist at London St Thomas’ Hospital - NHS Lothian, said: “The NICE guidelines and the NICE advice on ‘what to call people with heart disease’ are all geared to people who are clinically asymptomatic, those with a mild heart disease and those who have an established course of heart disease.”
This guideline states:
- Those with no clinical features are advised to get involved in ‘cardioprotective lifestyle’ practices.
- They must be kept engaged in the ‘Cardioprotective Lifestyle Practice to Prevent CVD (CPLCP)’ – that is, make sure they get a weekly dose of advice (46 mg of vitamin B6, 1g of vitamin B12, 7 g of zinc, 4 g of copper, 20 g of phosphorus, 10 g of calcium, 5 g of magnesium and 1 g of iron) weekly plus at least 30 minutes of physical activity after meals or when they have lunch each day in the form of moderate physical activity, or an equivalent combination of moderate- to vigorous-intensity exercise, for a total of 3000 steps.
- Those whose heart disease is severe enough (or who have a diagnosis of coronary heart disease) are advised to get some advice in case the heart condition is on a life threatening course.
“It is important to remember that the majority of people who suffer from a heart attack come from low-income and/or deprived areas. Even people who are well receive little or no advice or treatment.”
Dr Thiek said: “However, we have very strong support and evidence for lifestyle programmes such as the CPLCP. They can be particularly beneficial in improving people’s heart health and reducing the risk of developing CVD.”
He continued: “While the risk of cardiovascular disease is highest when a person is already ill, we know that a good lifestyle will help to ward off a heart attack with or without symptoms.
“The advice gives us an opportunity to provide advice based on the latest evidence to those who have already had heart disease. The aim of the programme is to enable people to take an active approach to what a healthy lifestyle may possibly contain.
“At NICE UK we have a ‘cardioprotective lifestyle’ guideline which is particularly relevant to patients who are newly diagnosed with a heart disease.
“This is a very important guide, because many patients have already been told about the need to be actively involved in their own heart-healthy lifestyle.
“The NHS guidelines are useful but what matters is that people ask themselves what lifestyle change would be most helpful.
“On average only about 48% of people who are treated for heart disease are aware (or actively involved) of their risks and the need for a certain lifestyle change.”
Dr Thiek said: “We also strongly recommend that they be encouraged to learn how they can access NHS support if they were to seek help for their heart disease.
“It is important that people start or complete the NHS NHS Heart Health Service in line with the recommendations that we are promoting at NHS UK.
“The NHS Heart Health Service is a very important opportunity for young people and those who care for them to take their heart health seriously and learn about what they can do to help make it better.
“We are currently funding the ‘NHS Heart Health Service’ at over £10m.”
Dr Thiek said the guidelines provided for the NHS Heart Health Service were tailored to enable people to identify lifestyle changes that could be taken to prevent heart disease, which would result in saving time and from a greater patient satisfaction.
He said: “It’s important to remember that the majority of people who suffer from a heart disease are already ill, therefore what we need is more attention. We should target to these people if we are going to provide the best care they can – so they could be able to take control of the way they live their life and achieve their best potential.
“It’s always important to be supported to change their heart disease, but it’s also essential that patients want to be involved in the decision making in terms of their heart conditions.”
He added: “We want to help people think about their lifestyle change, and then make it a reality.
“We have a lot of patients who are already getting good health advice and motivation from their colleagues, or even from family members, because they are using the resources of the NHS within their own NHS care.”

1. Diet changes
Obesity has an impact on many of the other chronic diseases. According to the latest NICE guidelines, 15% of those with a BMI of ≥ 40 and 10% of those with a BMI of ≥ 30 are likely to have one of the key CVD risk factors and need more specific CVD prevention recommendations.
So, what diet advice would be the same as for people with a BMI ≥ 30 for CVD prevention, except for more targeted advice on calorie needs? The advice would be an individualised approach for the specific weight category, with recommendations on total and LDL cholesterol levels. That way, people would live healthier for longer and be more empowered to manage their weight and their CVD risk.
2. Exercise and physical activity
There has been a huge increase in the prevalence of obesity in recent years, with recent global rates of 29% of the population classed as obese in 20191. Weight-related obesity is estimated to be about 15% of premature mortality1, however, according to the same NICE guidelines, it is very important to reduce your weight by even 10% or 25% if you are obese2.
Obesity brings an increased likelihood of developing many of the common chronic conditions we are all familiar with. This includes some of the more common cardiovascular diseases3,12 such as:
- Heart disease
- Type 2 diabetes
- Kidney disease
- Osteoarthritis and osteoporosis
- Sleep disorders
- Heart attacks
- Heart failure
How much activity does everyone need? According to NICE, the recommended amount of activity is between 150 minutes a week of moderate aerobic activity (e.g. cycling, swimming) plus 75 minutes a week of vigorous aerobic activity (e.g. jogging, hiking) or body weight resistance (e.g. weight lifting) a week.
3. Diet changes
Reducing your total weight without changing the amount of caloric intake (energy) is not easy. We know that many people with obesity are unaware of their obesity status, so even if they have lost significant amounts of weight, are unlikely to be able to change their total energy intake without cutting back on certain foods.
In general, the healthier the food chain, the greater the likelihood you will gain any weight back after you cut back on your calories. While there is currently no single way to lose weight, research and evidence suggests that the ideal outcome in terms of weight loss is a healthy transition from obesity to normal body weight (weight loss of 5% to less than 15 kg after 1-5 years). A more healthy weight can be maintained to prevent death and other chronic diseases after 5 years of continuous loss of weight.
Which diet changes should people need to make?
What to watch for while making diet changes:
- Weight gain after dietary changes, particularly in the absence of sufficient exercise
- Not achieving the recommended daily calories (1500-2000 calories per day)
- Not losing weight after dieting
- Not reaching the recommended daily calorie limit of 1,600-2,000 calories per day
What to watch for while making exercise guidelines:
While most people will benefit from the same exercise guideline (10-15 min a day, 4 times a week), there is still a lot of variation. In fact, a number of different recommendations have been put forward because of the variety of types and different goals, or different exercise modes. The main health benefits of exercising consistently are reduced risk of disease, improved physical fitness and increased quality of life.
So, which types of exercise need a different approach? A range of exercise has been found to be beneficial and safe for people with mild, moderate and severe cardiovascular disease, but not for people with severe obesity.
For example, in the UK, researchers found that 20 minutes of moderate exercise four to six days per week was associated with reduced cardiometabolic risks in both men and women.
However, 80-90% of people do not meet the exercise guidelines
At the heart of this research was a strong correlation between exercise and improved quality of life, so it is safe to assume that the same exercise guidance applies to more people with moderate-to-severe cardiovascular disease when trying to achieve a better quality of life, regardless of weight.

An important feature of this study, and the focus of further investigations, is the assessment of the risk factors associated with CVD. It used a cohort model, i.e., the probability of having CVD for a given health outcome was calculated based on information from the participants, including age, sex, BMI, and other relevant information. This allows researchers to identify risk groups based on information that might have not been recognized previously.
This study focused on data from the National Health and Morbidity Survey in China between the years 1999 and 2005, of which 557,581 were included in this analysis, as well as data from the National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey 2003, of which 594,605 were included in the analysis on the basis of age, sex, and health outcomes. The total CVD burden was calculated by using the national average for age, sex, and BMI and the prevalence of CVD was calculated based on the same national data as the earlier cohort study, for which it was analyzed as both a cohort study and a population based study.
Using the incidence data for stroke, dementia, and chronic heart failure, the risk of CVD, in particular, cardiovascular mortality (including the development of cardiac problems), was calculated, and CVD was calculated as the risk of CVD with an index of 20 percent lower risk.
The total prevalence of CVD in this study was 15.1 percent, which was higher than the data published by the Centers for Disease Control in the United States reported in 2011. For a more comprehensive database with better epidemiological data on the Chinese population, CVD prevalence in this Chinese study was determined with a new approach. It was also possible to identify patients in the same age group as the previous cohort study from a much larger cohort of 3 million subjects that met all the study inclusion criteria and data from a previous cohort study. In addition, it was possible to determine whether there were differences between different CVD populations, and whether differences in lifestyle, lifestyle patterns, and smoking habits had an impact on CVD. In addition to the Chinese data, data was also included from the Canadian and United States health surveys with the data collection being conducted in 2015 among the Chinese population.
The study also found that CVD incidence was similar or higher among older Chinese people than among other age groups. This finding may indicate that people in this age group, including those with an average risk, are at increased risk in terms of age-specific CVD mortality.
It was discovered that the prevalence of CVD in Chinese people was higher than in other Asian populations, including people in the West Asian population. This was likely caused by the fact that the Chinese population population of the West Asian and Indian populations were much smaller than the Chinese populations in other countries, and because China is the largest economic and population leader in the world. The Chinese people had a much higher overall risk of CVD, including heart disease, in comparison with other Asian populations.
Furthermore, individuals with higher cardiovascular parameters in this study were more likely to develop CVD in the following years: stroke, cognitive defects, high blood pressure, and elevated cholesterol. A combination of these factors contributed together to an increased risk of CVD.
To provide a baseline for future studies examining the Chinese population’s overall health, they included a 10-year cohort study where the subjects are asked about potential CV causes. The 10-year cohort showed that the cardiovascular parameters of the Chinese population in this study were significantly higher than the Chinese population in other Asian populations. Furthermore, a higher proportion of people in this cohort were diagnosed with a cardiovascular disease (CVD) during the study period. These findings may not be consistent for Asian populations and could be partially explained by the variation in epidemiological data between the countries examined, among other factors. However, a national study for CVD screening has been conducted in China since 2013 and is part of the government’s long-term effort to reduce the burden of cardiovascular diseases and cancer and improve the outcomes of those who are affected by them. In the long run, more focus is needed on controlling and reducing CVD diseases, including heart disease.

"These medications can be taken and used without difficulty, and may be effective in the prevention of cardiovascular diseases," said senior author Dr. Anita W. Kearney, MD.
